Posts.Content: Hi Guy, When I investigated the Pittsburgh area for SBRT I had a hard time finding RO's using SBRT for PCa. They had the equipment; but, I had no luck finding anyone using it for PCa. The standard of care in our area for beam radiation is IMRT. We traveled to the Cleveland Clinic for treatment. My Dr. there said it was his opinion that SBRT would replace IMRT in the relatively near future. My experience was terrific. No pain, no long recovery, short treatment, no pads, no ED, no fatigue just the expected reduction in ejaculate. So far...so good. Traveling 2 1/2 hours each way for treatments was very much worth it for us.
Posts.Signature: Rising PSA 10/16 5.94 TRUS 1/17 Bx: three of twelve cores positive low volume Gleason 6(3+3) no pni. DOB: 7/21/47 69 years old at Dx good health Family history of Pca uncles both sides SBRT @ Cleveland Clinic 6/17 Reduction in ejaculate volume only side effect. Everything works. PSA 3 mo. post treatment 1.1
Posts.Title: SBRT Near Raleigh, NC

Posts.Content: Denis, I've followed your posts on this as well as another forum and know and understand your commitment to learning as much about this disease as possible and an additional commitment to helping others. No one can tell you what treatment you should select since that's a very personal decision and everyone's situation and values is different. The best treatment would be what's best for you. As far as determining that I can only share my story and how I made my decision. If it doesn't help you it might help others following this thread. No matter what choice you make I would encourage everyone to learn as much as possible about their disease and seek out the very best practitioners they can find. After several years of rising PSA my family Dr. said it was time to see a Urologist. I asked what to expect from that visit and he said to expect a DRE and a probably biopsy. That's exactly what happened. Following the biopsy I got that phone call from my Urologist saying three of the twelve samples were positive with low volume Gleason 6. During the four weeks between that phone call and my follow-up visit with the Urologist I set about learning as much as possible about a disease I previously knew little about. My Urologist spent a lot of time going over the biopsy results, Partin Tables, statistics etc. and said if I elected to be treated he could remove the prostate or do Brachytherapy. With my newly acquired information I had a ton of questions including the different radiation options. He could answer some and others he confessed that I probably had more knowledge than he did. He suggested I consult with a Radiation Oncologist about the various beam radiation options since he was not familiar with them. He also said that my cancer was slow growing and that I had plenty of time to make an informed decision. I first looked at surgery to remove this cancer from my body; however, on deeper investigation I was very concerned about the relatively high rate of incontinence, ED, and a recovery time measured in months and the statistics that showed for a low risk guy like myself the cure rate was no higher than radiation. The quality of life issues were a real concern. Although I was 69 yo. I was in good health, despite three total joint replacements (arthritis) and remain very active. Pads, pills, pumps, injections, etc. caused us to quickly rule out surgery even though it had a significant advantage of knowing exactly how much cancer was present from the post operative pathology. The Partin Tables for my situation suggested that my cancer was fully contained so that advantage become much less important to us. Our local community hospital does Brachytherapy and I could do that with my Urologist in our home town. We live about an hour from Pittsburgh and although we have a lot of hospitals some associated with Universities the standard of care was IMRT with approximately 40-45 fractions (treatments). I had investigated SBRT (five fractions); however, I could not find anyone in Western PA using their SBRT equipment to treat PCa. I did find that Cleveland Clinic (CCF) offered all of the radiation options that I was interested in. Unfortunately CCF was 'out of network' for our insurance. We were able to work with our insurance and get an exemption for a consult with CCF. Following a more than two hour consult with a couple of Dr.'s and staff we came to the conclusion that I was an excellent candidate for SBRT. A lot of that two hours was spent discussing active surveillance. However, my three joint replacements would have been placed at unnecessary risk from the repeated biopsies necessary under AS. My treatment was very easy. We had a total of eight trips including one for the consult, one for the placement of the markers necessary to precisely guide the radiation, the third one for the imaging and simulation and then visits four though eight for the actual radiation treatments lasting less than ten minutes each. In addition to the loss of ejaculate I did have some mild burning on urination that lasted about a week or ten days. That resolved on its own with medication. I was able to maintain my active gym life including spinning classes (stationary bicycle) etc. throughout treatment. I drove the two and one half hour trips each way to Cleveland without any problems. Although it might not be for everyone, I'm very happy with my treatment choice. Statistics suggest that I have the same chance for a complete cure as if I had BT, IMRT, or surgery and five fractions verses forty five was a bonus.
Posts.Signature: Rising PSA 10/16 5.94 TRUS 1/17 Bx: three of twelve cores positive low volume Gleason 6(3+3) no pni. DOB: 7/21/47 69 years old at Dx good health Family history of Pca uncles both sides SBRT @ Cleveland Clinic 6/17 Reduction in ejaculate volume only side effect. Everything works. PSA 3 mo. post treatment 1.1
Posts.Title: Which Treatment????

Posts.Content: Denis, I'm not against surgery. For some guys it clearly is the best choice; having that pathology in hand can be very important. Also, those guys whose BPH maybe controlling their lives might see a benefit from removing the prostate. However; for my situation the form of radiation I chose treated the area (margins) around the prostate to 'catch' cancer tissue that might be on the way out. That was also a consideration. It can be difficult to treat these areas with surgical removal. Focus on what's important to you then find who does it best.

Posts.Title: Which Treatment????

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rjb1234 You are correct that I am not 100% . My understanding is that I am meeting a team to evaluate my pathology ang look at all options. I will verify this. I am quite confused on radiation as both urologists I have met say it is a poor option for someone my age. I will be sure to meet with a radiologist though. Thank you. You may not be ready to make an informed decision unless you fully understand the pluses and minuses of each treatment option. Did your Urologist fully explain how long recovery time would be or what side effects you might have. There are side effects probable and possible with each treatment and it's very important to understand them. Radiation or surgery both have equal cure rates for a guy with your statistics. Although younger guys typically recover quicker from surgery they also potentially have many more years to live with the side effects of their choice of treatment. It's to your advantage to learn as much as possible about each treatment choice. Keep learning, keep asking questions and keep us posted. Forums like this on is a good starting point.

Posts.Title: deciphering test results and figuring out treatment path

Posts.Content: It's my understanding that the post radiation tissue left behind is no longer like the original prostate tissue before radiation and that it is very unlikely to promote new Pcs. I know mine currently does not produce normal ejaculate. What I produce now may come from the Cowpers gland. Every study I looked at showed the recurrence rate for RT was equal to RP. A lot of the studies actually gave the success edge to high dose radiation treatments like SBRT and HDBT. There is little question in my mind from following a couple of different forums that I see far more posts from the side effects of RP than RT. My surgeon said he could remove my prostate and the cancer. He said I could regain most of my urinary function in a year at so. He said most guys respond pretty well to medications that help with erections. He did not say I should expect penile shortening or mention I might ejaculate some urine during climax if I could achieve an erection. I took my chances with radiation and have no regrets. The studies I investigated including Dr. Kings 10 year results suggest that any future ED is only equal to that of untreated men. For me I found little value in a post surgical pathology of my prostate when weighed against the quality of life issues surgery presented. Just my two cents.

Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: I apologize to any of the surgery guys I may have offended by my earlier post. I had no intention of doing so. I know I have a bias to my treatment choice and I know a lot of surgery guys do as well. Although I do recognize the benefits of surgery I have difficulty with so many Urologists not presenting RT as an option. I can't tell you how many guys I've talked to that thought surgery was their only option. Upon hearing they had Prostate Cancer they walked out of the office with surgery being scheduled. When I asked why they didn't consult with a Radiation Oncologist they said they didn't know that was an option or they had an entirely out dated understanding of the differences between treatments. I feel strongly that a lot of guys would benefit from at least being better informed. I don't whom to blame...the medical community or us the consumer?

Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Owen, I'm glad that you caught this early and that all indications are that the cancer is contained. After meeting with my Urolgist on the first appt. following diagnosis I thought removal was my best option. I also heard the part where they say once you have radiation you can no longer have surgery. Upon further investigation I found that was misleading. If your cancer returns following surgery it's almost certain you'll have radiation. If your cancer returns following radiation you will have the same radiation. I would focus on success rather than failure. Continue to learn, and question everything. You can only make the best decision after exploring all the options. The most challenging aspect of this disease for low and intermediate risk guys is that all the treatment options are available and they each carry different risks. You want to get this right. Good luck on the journey and take your time. I'm glad I didn't jump at the first treatment offered.

Posts.Content: Denis, I've followed your posts on two different forums. I appreciate your contributions, and they show the effort you've put into understanding this disease. May I ask your opinion regarding surgery verses radiation. It seems to me that both HDBT or SBRT would be viable mono therapies even if your Dx places you in the intermediate range. I'm not very familiar with the genetic testing; but, your PSA and Bx suggests the PCa is still fully contained and that radiation would be equally effective as surgery for a complete cure. Good luck and please keep posting. BTW I just had my first post treatment PSA and it was 1.1. Looking forward to an even lower level at 6 months.

Posts.Title: 3rd morning post RALP surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Darius, You have already received a lot of excellent advice that I hope you follow. As others have already pointed out bias do exist and I'd like to add mine with some explanation. I believe a lot of guys have confidence in their Urologist and he is the person most likely making the diagnosis. I know that was my situation and my first reaction to hearing you have cancer was to cut it out and get rid of it immediately. Fortunately I had four weeks from the time I got the phone call until my sit down with my Urologist to learn as much as possible about something I had little knowledge prior to. That time period proved to be a blessing. When we sat down to discuss my options I already had a ton of questions regarding the numerous treatment options. The surgery option seeming initially pretty clear and promising until I realized that "cutting it out" was not like simply removing your appendix. It is an extremely difficult operation to perform well and doing it open or with robotic assistance makes very little difference. The skill of the surgical team is all important. When I looked at the side effect statistics the quality of life issues were frightening. On forums like this one I found so much of the discussion centered around the side effects of surgery that I knew I had to investigate other options. As stated earlier the cure rate for most treated men is equal for both surgery and radiation. The radiation options were more numerous and harder to understand initially. Every treatment has potential side effects but the radiation options seemed to be easier to handle especially when I investigated the newer more sophisticated deliver systems. The SBRT treatment I eventually decided on has sub millimeter accuracy and I was able to be treated with 5 very easy sessions. I was fortunate to have almost no side effects with only some mild burning on urinating that resolved on it's own in about ten days without medication. These newer treatments are guided like smart bombs and not like the carpet bombing of old types. An important consideration was the radiation could be delivered precisely around the margins of the prostate while sparing the function of the organs nearby. I would encourage you to keep investigating to find what is in your best interest. Possibly even AS is still an option for you once you more fully understand the extent of your cancer. A followup biopsy could help swing in your favor. I did not have any urinary or GI problems prior to treatment. If I had urinary issues due to prostate size or other issues possibly that would have tilted my decision in another direction. What ever your decision I would urge you to seek out the very best practitioners you can find. Good luck and keep us posted.
Posts.Signature: Rising PSA 10/16 5.94 TRUS 1/17 Bx: three of twelve cores positive low volume Gleason 6(3+3) no pni. DOB: 7/21/47 69 years old at Dx good health Family history of Pca uncles both sides SBRT @ Cleveland Clinic 6/17 Reduction in ejaculate volume only side effect. Everything works. Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: Hi Darius, You have already received a lot of excellent advice that I hope you follow. As others have already pointed out bias do exist and I'd like to add mine with some explanation. I believe a lot of guys have confidence in their Urologist and he is the person most likely making the diagnosis. I know that was my situation and my first reaction to hearing you have cancer was to cut it out and get rid of it immediately. Fortunately I had four weeks from the time I got the phone call until my sit down with my Urologist to learn as much as possible about something I had little knowledge prior to. That time period proved to be a blessing. When we sat down to discuss my options I already had a ton of questions regarding the numerous treatment options. The surgery option seeming initially pretty clear and promising until I realized that "cutting it out" was not like simply removing your appendix. It is an extremely difficult operation to perform well and doing it open or with robotic assistance makes very little difference. The skill of the surgical team is all important. When I looked at the side effect statistics the quality of life issues were frightening. On forums like this one I found so much of the discussion centered around the side effects of surgery that I knew I had to investigate other options. As stated earlier the cure rate for most treated men is equal for both surgery and radiation. The radiation options were more numerous and harder to understand initially. Every treatment has potential side effects but the radiation options seemed to be easier to handle especially when I investigated the newer more sophisticated deliver systems. The SBRT treatment I eventually decided on has sub millimeter accuracy and I was able to be treated with 5 very easy sessions. I was fortunate to have almost no side effects with only some mild burning on urinating that resolved on it's own in about ten days without medication. These newer treatments are guided like smart bombs and not like the carpet bombing of old types. An important consideration was the radiation could be delivered precisely around the margins of the prostate while sparing the function of the organs nearby. I would encourage you to keep investigating to find what is in your best interest. Possibly even AS is still an option for you once you more fully understand the extent of your cancer. A followup biopsy could help swing in your favor. I did not have any urinary or GI problems prior to treatment. If I had urinary issues due to prostate size or other issues possibly that would have tilted my decision in another direction. What ever your decision I would urge you to seek out the very best practitioners you can find. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: There are far more LINAC's capable of delivering SBRT (hypofractionated beam radiation) than there are Radiation Oncologists using that equipment for SBRT to treat PCa. The reasons for that sometimes have little to do with the effectiveness of the SBRT treatment itself. Sometimes it's simply how slowly newer forms of treatment become accepted; and, sometimes economics becomes the driver. Our insurance companies and Medicare reimburse RO's based on the number of radiation (fractions) delivered. With standard IMRT you typically are given 40-45 fractions (hyperfractionated) lower rate doses. With SBRT typically only five higher dose fractions are delivered. With SBRT the fractions have to be delivered more precisely and the RO's and their entire team (Radiation technitions, dosimitrists, PA's, etc.) have to be more skilled. As a result our medical providers maybe reluctant to adopt a newer treatment that pays less and requires more skill even if the results and convenience are better for the patient. I'm not sure how to fix the system. In my case I did point out to my insurance provider that My treatment choice saved them money. Possibly we need a better reimbursement system that pays a premium for outstanding results?

Keep posting; the details of your experience certainly helps others on the same journey.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: GMJJ, If your husband's cancer is still contained within the prostate both radiation and surgery offer the same cure rates. That's very important to grasp and fully understand. I would focus on what practitioner within my system performs their specialty best. MUSC appears to offer SBRT for prostate cancer. If they do it well it can be one of the most effective ways of treating this disease. For me it was five easy treatments plus simulation and marker placement. I traveled a couple hours each way for treatment and had almost zero side effects. If you have any concerns about the skill of your surgeon I certainly would fully investigate RT options.

Posts.Title: Criteria for choosing Surgeon

Posts.Content: GMJJ, I can understand your husband's concern after the lose of his brother. I'm not an expert but my experience with my biopsy was that it was much easier than I expected and it would not have kept me from driving 9 hours three days post. That said why not reschedule to reduce any concern. The only way to diagnose PCa is a biopsy. I think either the Dr. misspoke or was misinterpreted. There are other causes for an increase in PSA besides PCa so don't get ahead of yourselves. And even if the biopsy is positive for most men the challenge is deciding how best to weigh through all of the options. All the statistics are still in your favor.

Posts.Title: Sticky: What I Need to Know About SBRT & IMRT

Posts.Content: You've receive good advice so far and I can understand wishing to avoid another surgery. My advice is to seek out the very best medical advice you can and get a second opinion at Cleveland Clinic just up the road. You obviously have a number of medical complications and CCF you have both a world class Urologyy facility as well as the Taussig Cancer Center. I would urge you to learn as much as possible about your treatment options. Each treatment carries equal chance for a cure; however, each has side effects and some of them very significant. Keep posting and I'm sure guys here can provide both support and help from personal experience.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer concerns

Posts.Content: Hi Liz, Please don't panic. From the limited information posted it appears your Dad's cancer most likely is one that is very, very slow growing. The best thing to do right now is to learn as much as possible and along with Dad's help take charge. One of the most challenging aspects of this disease is there are so many treatment options to consider. Although they all have pretty much an equal chance for a complete cure they each have pluses and minuses regarding treatment and quality of life side effects. I encourage you to study an learn about each as well as consult with the best practitioners in each field. This forum and others like it are a good starting point. Don't be afraid to ask questions It's the best way to learn. Some of the information out there can be a little biased. Most likely your Urologist is a surgeon who knows a great deal about that treatment; however, he probably has little experience with radiation options including the most up to date ones. Similarly a Radiation Oncologist knows little about surgery. I encourage you to consult with both. Your Dad's choices should be based on what's important to him and his unique personal and medical situation. If you post your location members reading your post might have specific recomendations. Feel free to message me if you think I can be of any help.
Posts.Title: Dad just diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: SHARP is Sloan's spin on SBRT. Although the acronym maybe different based on equipment the hypofrationated treatment is pretty much the same. I'm approximately your hubby's age and I was treated at Cleveland Clinic where the call it SBRT. This treatment is overtaking other forms of radiation in a lot of men based on it's effectiveness, the shorter treatment times and usually with fewer side effects. Your very fortunate to have Sloan Kettering for treatment. With SHARP and Sloan Kettering I can't imagine having anyone be critical of that choice. SBRT is delivered much more accurately than older forms of beam radiation. With this treatment you also can have the margins (area outside but near the prostate) treated in case the cancer is in the process of spreading from the prostate gland. I found my treatment experience amazing. You do have to have markers placed in the prostate to guide the radiation delivery. It's a simple procedure that I found easier than the biopsy. You also have planning day with a lot of scans on a table similar to the treatment table. The five treatments are the easiest part. I had almost zero side effects during and following treatment. I had some very mild burning on urinating that lasted 7-10 days. It was so minor it did not require medication and resolved on it's own. I only point it out since that's all there was. When I look at this and other forums I find so many men having far worse issues with other treatments. SBRT may not be the best choice for every situation; however, if Sloan Kettering has recommended it for you I say go for it. Good luck and keep us posted.

DOB: 7/21/47 69 years old at Dx good health Family history of Pca uncles both sides SBRT @ Cleveland Clinic 6/17 Reduction in ejaculate volume only side effect. Everything works. Posts.Title: SHARP Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: Jules, What you and your husband are feeling is very typical and most of us have shared the same feelings. From the limited amount of information you have shared it sounds like your husband has prostate cancer that has a high chance for a complete cure. One of the difficult aspects of this disease is that most treatments will work. The challenge is selecting the 'one' that offers the best overall outcome for your situation. If you can share some additional information the members here can offer more informed advice. The specific information of your husbands biopsy is very important to how his cancer is classified. How many cores where taken (typically 12)? How many showed evidence of cancer, what was the percentage in each core showing cancer and where they all Gleason 7 (3 + 4)? How large was his prostate? What are the potential causes of his other urinary symptoms? Basically this information indicates the amount and the aggressiveness of his cancer and if BPH is also an issue. Learn about the Partin Tables. With your husbands biopsy results you can use the Partin Tables to provide information on how likely it is that your husbands cancer is confined to the prostate. This should be information that every diagnosing physician shares with their patient. If you can share what part of the world your from possibly members can provide suggestions on Dr's etc. If you want the best treatment and the best chance of complete success you need to do a little homework. This forum is a good place to start. To often we jump on the first recommendation and may spend more time selecting an automobile than a physician or treatment. As I've reminded others you maybe betting your life or at least the quality of your life on this decision. No matter how good your diagnosing physician (typically a Urologist) is he only is skilled in one or two treatment options. My Urologist (whom I have a great deal of trust and respect for) could offer surgery or seeds. When we asked about other treatments he suggested we consult with a Radiation Oncologist who could offer IMRT and SBRT and possibly HDBT. He said my cancer was very slow growing, low volume and that I had plenty of time to make an informed decision. I'm so glad we took that advice. Although I selected radiation treatment it may not be the best choice for everyone; I'm convinced it was the best for me. Be assured that there are plenty of people here willing to assist you on this journey.
Posts.Signature: Rising PSA 10/16 5.94 TRUS 1/17 Bx: three of twelve cores positive low volume Gleason 6(3+3) no pni. DOB: 7/21/47 69 years old at Dx good health Family history of Pca uncles both sides SBRT @ Cleveland Clinic 6/17 Reduction in ejaculate volume only side effect. Everything works. Posts.Title: Feeling confused

Posts.Content: Jules, I hope your hubby can resolve the source of his other symptoms. Sometimes an inflammation of the prostate unrelated to the cancer can occur and lead to urinary issues. In any event it's probably fortunate that these symptoms led to an early detection of his cancer. Far too many men go undetected. Good luck on your treatment and keep us posted on his progress.

Posts.Content: Jules, I hope your hubby can resolve the source of his other symptoms. Sometimes an inflammation of the prostate unrelated to the cancer can occur and lead to urinary issues. In any event it's probably fortunate that these symptoms led to an early detection of his cancer. Far too many men go undetected. Good luck on your treatment and keep us posted on his progress.

Posts.Title: Feeling confused

Posts.Content: Jules, What you and your husband are feeling is very typical and most of us have shared the same feelings. From the limited amount of information you have shared it sounds like your husband has prostate cancer that has a high chance for a complete cure. One of the difficult aspects of this disease is that most treatments will work. The challenge is selecting the 'one' that offers the best overall outcome for your situation. If you can share some additional information the members here can offer more informed advice. The specific information of your husbands biopsy is very important to how his cancer is classified. How many cores where taken (typically 12)? How many showed evidence of cancer, what was the percentage in each core showing cancer and where they all Gleason 7 (3 + 4)? How large was his prostate? What are the potential causes of his other urinary symptoms? Basically this information indicates the amount and the aggressiveness of his cancer and if BPH is also an issue. Learn about the Partin Tables. With your husbands biopsy results you can use the Partin Tables to provide information on how likely it is that your husbands cancer is confined to the prostate. This should be information that every diagnosing physician shares with their patient. If you can share what part of the world your from possibly members can provide suggestions on Dr's etc. If you want the best treatment and the best chance of complete success you need to do a little homework. This forum is a good place to start. To often we jump on the first recommendation and may spend more time selecting an automobile than a physician or treatment. As I've reminded others you maybe betting your life or at least the quality of your life on this decision. No matter how good your diagnosing physician (typically a Urologist) is he only is skilled in one or two treatment options. My Urologist (whom I have a great deal of trust and respect for) could offer surgery or seeds. When we asked about other treatments he suggested we consult with a Radiation Oncologist who could offer IMRT and SBRT and possibly HDBT. He said my cancer was very slow growing, low volume and that I had plenty of time to make an informed decision. I'm so glad we took that advice. Although I selected radiation treatment it may not be the best choice for everyone; I'm convinced it was the best for me. Be assured that there are plenty of people here willing to assist you on this journey.

Posts.Title: Feeling confused

Posts.Content: SHARP is Sloan's spin on SBRT. Although the acronym maybe different based on equipment the hypofrationated treatment is pretty much the same. I'm approximately your hubby's age and I was treated at Cleveland Clinic where the call it SBRT. This treatment is overtaking other forms of radiation in a lot of men based on it's effectiveness, the shorter treatment times and usually with fewer side effects. Your very fortunate to have Sloan Kettering for treatment. With SHARP and Sloan Kettering I can't imagine having anyone be critical of that choice. SBRT is delivered much more accurately than older forms of beam radiation. With this treatment you also can have the margins (area outside but near the prostate) treated in case the cancer is in the process of spreading from the prostate gland. I found my treatment experience amazing. You do have to have markers placed in the prostate to guide the radiation delivery. It's a simple procedure that I found easier than the biopsy. You also have planning day with a lot of scans on a table similar to the treatment table. The five treatments are the easiest part. I had almost zero side effects during and following treatment. I had some very mild burning on urinating that lasted 7-10 days. It was so minor it did not require medication and resolved on it's own. I only point it out since that's all there was. When I look at this and other forums I find so many men having far worse issues with other treatments. SBRT may not be the best choice for every situation; however, if Sloan Kettering has recommended it for you I say go for it. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Feeling confused

Posts.Content: Danny, I found my marker placement even easier than the biopsy; however, each physician may have different protocols. Some prefer a perineal approach and others transrectal (TRUS) like the Bx. Mine was TRUS with some kind of local numbing agent given. I felt almost nothing except the pressure of the US wand. I did have some staining of my ejaculate. Can't offer anything on the perineal method. My SBRT was delivered using a Varian Edge machine and that part (5 fractions) of the experience was a piece of cake. My only side effect was some mild burning on urinating that started after the third fraction and lasted about seven or ten days. It was very mild and resolved on it's own without medication. I only even point it out since it was all the negative I can find through my treatment. I was able to drive the two and half hours each way to treatment without issue as well as maintain my normal active life style including my exercise program at the YMCA. I hope your experience turns out as well as mine. Feel free to message me if you have additional questions and I'll also continue to monitor this thread. Keep us posted on your progress.
